title: ICE's Backdoor Into a Nationwide AI Surveillance Network

How does it work? How common is it?
Yeah, so Flock is an automated license
plate reader camera. Um, it basically
like sits at different intersections or
just different places on a road and it
scans the license plates of cars as they
drive by. And
Flock, I believe it's the most popular
one. It's at least the like it's it's
one that's used by different homeowners

groups. Um, you know, there's also a
Motorola one that is extremely widely
used, but Flock is sort of like a a
Silicon Valley startup who CEO has said
that he wants to like use these
to get rid of crime everywhere. And so,
like, that's the pitch is like put these
in and over time we will completely
eliminate crime, which is obviously like
a very, very, very lofty claim.
And so over the last few years, they've
kind of gone state by state, city by
city, trying to sell these both to like
neighborhood watch groups and shopping
malls and and places like that, but then
also of course to the police, to local
police. And so over time, uh there has
become a very large network of flocked
cameras. So, it's not just, you know,
the city of Dallas that has access to
flock cameras. It's like once you're in
it, you can query the cameras of other
uh states and municipalities. You can do

stolen vehicle."
And you're not just searching the

and like paid the subscription fee for.
You can search all the ones in your

you want to. Um, so it's become this

of it. Is that the ability to find and

it's not chat GPT but it is AI or

what is this data that we got
yeah so very
crucially there is something that cops

they're pinging their database of like

if they're if someone says like like a

Flock Network it says

Uh sometimes it just says ICE, sometimes

basically, this shows that
uh local cops around the country were

they were doing it on behalf of the

and also ICE. So, if I'm the FBI and I'm

That is not exactly what we're seeing

which ICE is a part. So right now the
feds
supposedly do not have the software that

They they haven't procured Flock which
has you know a process where they're

kind of legally allowed to use it
because they bought it. What's happening
here is local police are doing these

emailed probably like 20 of them. And
what they're saying is in some cases

the feds are saying, "Hey, look this up.

it's something that they're
like it's a service that they're paying

not getting warrants. And so what's

because like experts I talked to both

basically they're getting like
unofficial access to this incredibly

local police and there's like no

so like sure I I believe that ICE could

unofficial

at the

So, a few things.
One, I've learned over the last I mean a
lot of people probably have known this
for a while, but I've learned reporting
on this and the massive blue story that
we did a few like a month ago
that generally local and state police do
not have jurisdiction over
immigration matters. Like they are not
allowed to say, "Hey, you're in the
country illegally. We are going to
detain you." Like that is specifically a
federal function.
But what Trump has done and what Trump
has become very like obsessed with is
the idea of empowering local police to
enforce immigration laws. And they've
done that through this program called
287G, which
is it's just like an ICE program that uh
different police departments have to
apply to. And then ICE says, "Okay, we
are empowering you. It's like a
delegation is what it's called. we're
delegating you to you the authority to
conduct some like immigration
enforcement type stuff. So the concern
here is that
like this incredibly powerful nationwide
network of license plate cameras is
going to be used to you know pick up
people for ICE. also that uh this
surveillance network has been built,
this like apparatus has been built
largely by going community to community
and saying like we're going to use this
to find stolen cars or we're going to
use this to uh you know help prevent or
solve really violent crime things like
that. and a lot like Flock is in a lot
of liberal neighborhoods like largely
according to both what we've reported on
but also the experts that I spoke to
like a lot of them were saying it's like
rich people trying to protect their
homes and stuff like that
and by and large like at city council
meetings where they discuss like should
we buy this should we not they're like
oh we're going to use this to solve

accidentally opted themselves into this
large surveillance network that is being

about different searches that they ran
and they were like oh yeah like that it
someone on our force did that search,
but we don't like exactly know why. So,
can you talk a bit
because you point out the the legal

agencies with immigration
stuff? You're pointing out that the
reason field in the searches very
clearly says that these are immigration
or ICE issues. and they say what like
what are the responses to to that
contradiction?
Yeah. I mean sometimes so it it's ends
up being like a quite a complicated
story in some ways because this came
from Illinois which is one of the few
states that actually explicitly bans
their police from working with ICE. Uh
they have a they have a law that is
basically makes it like a sanctuary

then I show them like a spread a
spreadsheet thing that says, "Well, it
it says here that you did this for im
quote immigration violation or something

yeah, but that was like a specific
criminal case, and yes, the person might
have been illegal or undocumented or or

legal immigration status, but that's not
what it was for. And in many cases, they
they weren't able to tell me what it was
specifically for either because they

straight up like we actually don't know

know why it said immigration there
because like I believe it's because
access to flock is just like so
widespread. It's like it was described

as like a Google search engine for cars.
So, it's like, "Oh, I'm doing this case
gonna go on Flock and like type in what
I'm looking for." And because there's
like very few restrictions on how it's
used, cops are just using it for like
whatever. And it's like if I asked you,
why did you Google that thing 3 weeks

even more to the point, if someone asked

I'll be like, maybe it was for this
story, but I have no idea what it was
actually for. And so it seems like
access to this like massive surveillance
network is now so common place that the
cops don't even know like why they are
searching it half of the time.
Um, and I just I think that that's like
very notable actually because we've
built a system that can track the
movements of anyone with a car in the
United States, which many of these
communities are unlivable without a car.
Like you need a car to go anywhere. And
at first this was a technology that was

like surveillance apparatus and it's

Ring. I don't need to get into it to it,

people
understand the the pro the issue or like
